text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Welcome to 6 Minute English, where we bring you an intelligent topic and six related items of vocabulary. I’m Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: I'm Neil and I'm Tim and today we are talking about AI or artificial intelligence.
Artificial intelligence is the ability of machines to copy human intelligent behaviour.
For example, an intelligent machine can learn from its own mistakes and make decisions based
on what's happened in the past.
There’s a lot of talk about AI these days, Neil, but it’s still just science fiction, isn’t it?
speaker: Tim

text: That's not true. AI is everywhere.
Machine thinking is in our homes, offices, schools and hospitals.
Computer algorithms are helping us drive our cars.
They're diagnosing what's wrong with us in hospitals.
They're marking student essays.
They're telling us what to read on our smartphones.
Well, that really does sound like science fiction – but it’s happening already, you say, Neil?
speaker: Tim

text: But it's happening already, you say, Neil.
It's definitely happening, Tim.
And an algorithm, by the way, is a set of steps a computer follows in order to solve a problem.
So can you tell me what was the name of the computer
which famously beat world chess champion Gary Kasparov using algorithms in 1997?
Was it A, how? B, alpha 60 or C, deep blue?
I’ll say Deep Blue. Although I’m just guessing.
speaker: Tim

text: Was it an educated guess, Tim?
speaker: Neil

text: I know a bit about chess…
speaker: Tim

text: An educated guess is based on knowledge and experience and is therefore likely to be correct. Well, we’ll find out later on how educated your guess was in this case, Tim!
speaker: Neil

text: Well, we'll find out later on how educated your guess was in this case, Tim.
Indeed. But getting back to AI and what machines can do.
Are they any good at solving real-life problems?
Computers think in zeros and ones, don't they?
That sounds like a pretty limited language when it comes to life experience.
You would be surprised at what those zeros and ones can do, Tim.
Although you're right that AI does have its limitations at the moment.
And if something has its limitations, there's a limit on what it can do or how good it can be.
Okay. Well, now it might be a good time to listen to Zubin Bachramani,
professor of information engineering at the University of Cambridge,
and Deputy Director of the Leverhulmer Center for the Future of Intelligence.
He's talking about what limitations AI has at the moment.
I think it's very interesting how many of the things that we take for granted,
we humans take for granted as being sort of things we don't even think about, like,
how do we walk, how do we reach, how do we recognize our mother, all these things.
When you start to think about how to implement them on a computer,
you realize that it's those things that are incredibly difficult to get computers to do,
and that's where the current cutting edge of research is.
If we take something for granted, we don't realize how important something is.
You sometimes take me for granted, I think, Neil.
speaker: Tim

text: No – I never take you for granted, Tim! You’re far too important for that!
speaker: Neil

text: Good to hear. So things we take for granted are doing everyday tasks,
like walking, picking something up, or recognizing somebody.
We implement or perform these things without thinking,
whereas it's cutting edge research to try and program a machine to do them.
Cutting edge means very new and advanced.
It's interesting, isn't it, that over 10 years ago, a computer beat a chess grandmaster,
but the same computer would find it incredibly difficult to pick up a chess piece.
I know. It’s very strange. But now you’ve reminded me that we need the answer to today’s question.
speaker: Tim

text: which was, what was the name of the computer which famously beat world chess champion Gary Kasparov in 1997?
Now you said deep blue Tim, and that was the right answer.
You see, my educated guess was based on knowledge and experience!
speaker: Tim

text: Oh, maybe you were just lucky.
So the IBM Supercomputer deep blue played against US World Chess champion Gary Kasparov in two
chess matches. The first match was played in Philadelphia in 1996 and was won by Kasparov.
The second was played in New York City in 1997 and won by deep blue.
The 1997 match was the first defeat of a reigning world chess champion by a computer under tournament
conditions. Let's go through the words we learned today. First up was artificial intelligence or AI,
the ability of machines to copy human intelligent behavior.
“There are AI programs that can write poetry.”
speaker: Neil

text: Do you have any examples you can recite?
speaker: Tim

text: Afraid I don't.
Number two, an algorithm is a set of steps a computer follows in order to solve a problem.
For example, Google changes its search algorithm hundreds of times every year.
The adjective is algorithmic – for example, “Google has made many algorithmic changes.”
speaker: Tim

text: Number three – if something has ‘limitations’ – there’s a limit on what it can do or how good it can be. “Our show has certain limitations – for example, it’s only six minutes long!”
speaker: Neil

text: Our show has certain limitations. For example, it's only six minutes long.
That’s right – there’s only time to present six vocabulary items. Short but sweet!
speaker: Tim

text: Okay, the next item is take something for granted, which is when we don't realise how important
something is. We take our smartphones for granted these days, but before 1995, hardly anyone owned one.
Number five – ‘to implement’ – means to perform a task, or take action.
speaker: Neil

text: “Neil implemented some changes to the show.”
speaker: Tim

text: The final item is ‘cutting edge’ – new and advanced – “This software is cutting edge.”
speaker: Neil

text: This software is cutting edge.
“The software uses cutting edge technology.”
speaker: Tim

text: Okay, that's all we have time for in today's cutting edge show,
OK – that’s all we have time for on today’s cutting edge show. But please check out our Instagram, Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages.
speaker: Neil

text: Bye bye, goodbye.
